   Lactic Acid:0.8 mmol/L, Ca++:7.9 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7 mg/dL, PO4:3.7 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p
   prior MI)who presents with new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration
   event in setting of hemoptysis vs. GI bleed.
   .
   #COPD Exacerbation / resp acidosis/hemoptysis: Patient presumably
   desaturated secondary to acute COPD exacerbation from coughing,
   aspiration and bronchospasm in the setting of  and elevated INR of
   3.8.  This acute aspiration paired with his poor baseline lung reserve
   with severe COPD & asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his
   hypoxia at OSH with desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was
   successfully intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC
   mode.  Required bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday
   with evidence of RUL posterior segment bleed.  He has no leukocytosis
   or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5 range - but this is
   also in the differential as RLL on CT chest  with concerning
   consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   .
   - respiratory acidosis, increase RR to decrease carbon dioxide (watch
   out for auto-peep)
   - try to switch to PSV if tolerates
   - repeat ABG
   - try to wean down sedation
   - continue CTX / Vanco, start Azithromycin
   - prednisone PO 60mg, will taper slowly
   - albuterol/atrovent MDIs standing q6hrs.
   - place PPD and control to assess for Tb
   - RUL bronchoscopy for fungal , gram stain and cultures
   .
   #Anemia: Stable Hct drop between [**Date range (1) 8478**] from 42-> 38-> 36 -> 31 now.
   Given dark NG lavage and small amount suctioned (20cc). While initial
   concern was for GI or nasopharyngeal source, bronch yesterday showed
   evidence of pulmonary bleed.  Etiology of hemoptysis may be due Strep
   PNA vs. complications from underlying existing asbestosis related lung
   disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also possible new
   malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early [**2199-6-7**] at
   last cardiology appointment), however, there are no clear masses to
   support this on CT.
   .
   - continue trending Hct  q6 hours
   - active T&S
   - supportive management
   - if Hct continues to decrease will contact IR for possible
   embolization, surgery for possible emergent thoracotomy, anesthesia to
   possibly place double lumen tube in non-bleeding bronchus
   - if cont active hemoptysis place patient on right side
   - if continue to bleed reverse anticoagulation with FFP, hold heparin
   for now
   -guiac all stools
   -continue IV Protonix [**Hospital1 7**] for GI source coverage
   -consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding
   -f/up final CT chest read
   -INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA
   -transfuse if Hct drops <30
   # hypotension: likely multifactorial due to hypovolemia, acute volume
   loss (low urine output), cardiac dysfunction with bradycardia.  Holding
   home antihypotensives.
   - high autopeep and sepsis less likely etiologies
   - repeat ECHO
   - supportive management with fluid boluses
   - RBC transfusion as needed
   - place arterial line, consider central line if pt does not improve
   with boluses and continuous pressure monitoring.
   .
   #COPD-Longstanding history per family. Per daughter he is usually on
   2.5L NC at home, not 1.5L per OSH records.
   -trending ABGs as above
   -restart Advair, albuterol nebs, Spiriva regimen
   .
   #History of MI: No recent note of any chest pain alongside his SOB
   complaints. CKs and troponins all negative at OSH and no concerning
   ischemic EKG changes.
   - holding ASA for now given bleeding
   - repeat EKG
   - TTE
   - continue tele monitoring
   .
   #HTN
 holding home meds [**3-11**] hypotension; d/ced lisinopril 5mg, lasix
   20mg
   .
   #H/O arrhythmia: Initially unclear of why patient was on Warfarin and
   Sotolol but confirmed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] ( cardiologist) that both for pAF.
   NSR now on telemetry and EKG.
   --holding Sotolol [**3-11**] hypotension
   --repeat EKG
   --continue telemetry
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: start tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2199-8-5**] 08:40 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2199-8-5**] 08:41 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazol
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: NOK daughter [**Name (NI) 3926**] [**Name (NI) 8479**] #[**Telephone/Fax (1) 8480**] ([**Last Name (un) **])
   and daughter [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 8481**] #[**Telephone/Fax (1) 8482**].
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 91-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory distress and hemoptysis. He has a history of severe COPD, CAD, and asbestosis-related lung disease.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure of 22 cmH2O, plateau pressure of 18 cmH2O, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is 107/48 mmHg, and his heart rate is 65 beats per minute.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received 3,657 mL of fluid and has a total output of 1,025 mL.
* Laboratory results:
	+ Complete blood count (CBC): WBC 5.3, Hct 31.4%, platelet count 211 K/uL
	+ Blood chemistry: Sodium 134 mg/dL, potassium 4.6 mEq/L, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
	+ Coagulation studies: International normalized ratio (INR) 2.7, partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 36.7 seconds
* Imaging studies:
	+ Chest computed tomography (CT): RUL posterior segment bleed
	+ Bronchoscopy: Evidence of pulmonary bleed
* Physical examination:
	+ General: Sedated, opens eyes to voice
	+ HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No conjunctival pallor. No scleral icterus. PERRLA/EOMI. MMM. OP clear.
	+ Cardiac: Regular rhythm, normal rate. Normal S1, S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallop.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and increased respiratory rate suggest a high risk of respiratory failure.
2. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis is likely due to a pulmonary bleed, which may be related to his underlying COPD and asbestosis-related lung disease.
3. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 9.9 g/dL, which is lower than normal. The etiology of anemia is unclear, but it may be related to chronic bleeding or underlying disease.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 107/48 mmHg, which is lower than normal. The etiology of hypotension is unclear, but it may be related to hypovolemia, acute volume loss, or cardiac dysfunction.
5. Sepsis: The patient's lactate level is 1.5 mmol/L, which is higher than normal. This suggests a high risk of sepsis.
6. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is 0.9 mg/dL, which is higher than normal. This suggests a high risk of acute kidney injury.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's heart rate is 65 beats per minute, which is lower than normal. This suggests a high risk of cardiovascular instability.

Based on the patient's condition, the following interventions are recommended:

1. Continue invasive ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure of 22 cmH2O and a FiO2 of 40%.
2. Monitor the patient's hemoglobin level and consider transfusing if it drops below 30 g/dL.
3. Continue anticoagulation therapy with heparin and monitor the patient's INR level.
4. Consider placing a pulmonary artery catheter to monitor the patient's cardiac output and pulmonary artery pressure.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider administering vasopressors if it drops below 90 mmHg.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory rate and consider administering bronchodilators if it increases above 20 breaths per minute.
7. Consider performing a bronchoscopy to evaluate the patient's airway and pulmonary parenchyma.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management.

   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p
   prior MI)who presents with new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration
   event in setting of hemoptysis vs. GI bleed.
   .
   #COPD Exacerbation / Hypoxia/hemoptysis: Patient presumably desaturated
   secondary to acute COPD exacerbation from coughing, aspiration and
   bronchospasm in the setting of  hemoptysis vs. nasopharyngeal bleeding
   source w/aspiration( given elevated INR 3.8).  This acute aspiration
   paired with his poor baseline lung reserve with severe COPD &
   asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his hypoxia at OSH with
   desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was successfully
   intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC mode.  Required
   bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday with evidence of He
   has no leukocytosis or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5
   range - but this is also in the differential as RLL on CT chest  with
   concerning consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   .
   -continue current settings on AC mode
   -repeat ABG
   -wean to CPAP/PS as tolerates, then to NC
   -expand Abx coverage with CTX / Vanco/ Azithromycin
   -prednisone PO 60mg, will taper slowly
   -albuterol/atrovent MDIs standing q6hrs.
   .
   #Anemia: Stable Hct drop between [**Date range (1) 8478**] from 42-> 38-> 36 now. Given
   dark NG lavage and small amount suctioned (20cc). This GI collected
   blood may be secondary to ingested hempotysis source or from a
   nasopharyngeal /nosebleed in the setting of an elevated INR vs. true
   pulmonary source and overt hemoptysis.  Etiology of hemoptysis may be
   due Strep PNA vs. complications from underlying existing asbestosis
   related lung disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also
   possible new malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early
   [**2199-6-7**] at last cardiology appointment), however, there are no clear
   masses to support this on CT.
   .
   -continue trending Hct
   -q6 hours Hct checks
   -active T&S
   -guiac all stools
   -continue IV Protonix [**Hospital1 7**] for GI source coverage
   -consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding
   -f/up final CT chest read
   -INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA

   .

   .

   ischemic EKG changes.

   --restart Sotolol after QT check

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 90-year-old male with a significant medical history, including hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease (CAD) with a prior myocardial infarction (MI). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory distress, hemoptysis, and hypoxia. The patient was intubated and placed on invasive ventilation.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.5°F)
* Heart rate: 65 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 107/48 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 5.3 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit (Hct): 36.5%
* Platelet count (Plt): 195 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.9 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphorus (PO4): 3.7 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Sedated, opens eyes to voice
* Normocephalic, atraumatic
* No conjunctival pallor, no scleral icterus
* PERRLA/EOMI
* Regular rhythm, normal rate
* Normal S1, S2
* No murmurs, rubs, or gallop

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Acute COPD exacerbation
* Hemoptysis
* Anemia
* Hypertension
* Coronary artery disease
* Asbestosis-related lung disease
* Potential new malignancy
* Pneumonia
* DVT
* Stress ulcer
* VAP

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue current settings on AC mode
* Repeat ABG
* Wean to CPAP/PS as tolerated, then to NC
* Expand antibiotic coverage with ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and azithromycin
* Start prednisone PO 60mg and taper slowly
* Albuterol/atropine MDIs standing q6 hours
* Trending Hct
* Q6 hours Hct checks
* Active T&S
* Guaiac all stools
* Continue IV protonix for GI source coverage
* Consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding
* F/U final CT chest read
* INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA
* Transfuse if Hct drops <30
* Restart Advair, albuterol nebs, and Spiriva regimen
* Holding ASA for now given bleeding
* Repeat EKG
* Continue tele monitoring
* Restart Sotolol after QT check
* Repeat EKG
* Continue telemetry
* Continue Protonix IV BID and INR therapeutic at 2.1 now, start pneumoboots for additional DVT prophylaxis

The patient's code status is full code, and his communication is with his daughters.

   asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his hypoxia at OSH with
   desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was successfully
   intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC mode.  Required
   bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday with evidence of He
   has no leukocytosis or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5
   range - but this is also in the differential as RLL on CT chest  with
   concerning consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   .
   - respiratory acidosis, increase RR to decrease carbon dioxide (watch
   out for auto-peep)
   - try to switch to PSV  if tolerates
   -repeat ABG
   - try to wean down sedation
   -continue CTX / Vanco/ Azithromycin
   -prednisone PO 60mg, will taper slowly
   -albuterol/atrovent MDIs standing q6hrs.
   .
   #Anemia: Stable Hct drop between [**Date range (1) 8478**] from 42-> 38-> 36 -> 31 now.
   Given dark NG lavage and small amount suctioned (20cc). This GI
   collected blood may be secondary to ingested hempotysis source or from
   a nasopharyngeal /nosebleed in the setting of an elevated INR vs. true
   pulmonary source and overt hemoptysis.  Etiology of hemoptysis may be
   due Strep PNA vs. complications from underlying existing asbestosis
   related lung disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also
   possible new malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early
   [**2199-6-7**] at last cardiology appointment), however, there are no clear
   masses to support this on CT.   Bronchoscopy showed possible source of
   bleeding in posterior RUL
   .
   -continue trending Hct  q6 hours
   -active T&S
   - supportive management
   - if Hct continues to decrease will contact IR for possible
   embolization, surgery for possible emergent thoracotomy, anesthesia to
   possibly place double lumen tube in non-bleeding bronchus
   -if cont active bleed place patient on right side
   -guiac all stools
   -continue IV Protonix [**Hospital1 7**] for GI source coverage
   -consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding
   -f/up final CT chest read
   -INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA
   -transfuse if Hct drops <30
   # hypotension: likely multifactorial due to hypovolemia, acute volume
   loss as patient has low urine output
   - high autopeep and sepsis less likely etiologies
   - supportive management with fluid boluses
   - RBC transfusion as needed
   .
   #COPD-Longstanding history per family. Per daughter he is usually on
   2.5L NC at home, not 1.5L per OSH records.
   -trending ABGs as above
   -restart Advair, albuterol nebs, Spiriva regimen
   .
   #History of MI: No recent note of any chest pain alongside his SOB
   complaints. CKs and troponins all negative at OSH and no concerning
   ischemic EKG changes.
   --holding ASA for now given bleeding
   --repeat EKG
   --continue tele monitoring
   .
   #HTN
 holding home meds [**3-11**] hypotension; lisinopril 5mg, lasix 20mg
   .
   #H/O arrhythmia: Initially unclear of why patient was on Warfarin and
   Sotolol but confirmed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] ( cardiologist) that both for pAF.
   NSR now on telemetry and EKG.
   --holding Sotolol [**3-11**] hypotension
   --repeat EKG

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with respiratory distress, hemoptysis, and possible aspiration event. The patient was intubated and is currently receiving invasive ventilation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and increased respiratory rate (RR) may lead to further respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's hemoptysis and possible aspiration event may increase the risk of developing pneumonia, which could further complicate his respiratory status.
3. Bleeding complications: The patient's bleeding from the right upper lobe (RUL) posterior segment may continue or worsen, requiring further management and possible embolization or surgery.
4. Anemia: The patient's stable Hct drop may indicate ongoing bleeding or hemolysis, which could lead to further anemia and potential transfusion requirements.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be multifactorial, and further management with fluid boluses and possible transfusion may be necessary to maintain adequate blood pressure.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of CAD and hypertension may increase his risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or acute coronary syndromes.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's dark nasogastric (NG) lavage and small amount of suctioned blood may indicate ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to further complications.
8. Infectious complications: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and invasive interventions may increase his risk of developing infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's inability to eat and his potential for prolonged hospitalization may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which could impact his recovery.
10. Cognitive decline: The patient's age and underlying medical conditions may increase his risk of cognitive decline, which could impact his ability to recover and respond to treatment.

To manage these potential complications, the patient should continue to receive close monitoring and management, including frequent assessments of his respiratory status, bleeding, and cardiovascular function. The patient's family should be kept informed of his condition and any changes that occur.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 91-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory distress and hemoptysis. He has a significant medical history, including hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease (CAD) with a previous myocardial infarction (MI).

The patient was intubated due to respiratory failure and is currently receiving invasive ventilation. He has been treated with bronchoscopy, which showed evidence of bleeding in the right upper lobe (RUL) posterior segment. The patient has also been diagnosed with anemia, and his hemoglobin (Hct) level has been trending downward.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 100% and a respiratory rate (RR) of 16 breaths per minute. His heart rhythm is sinus rhythm, and his blood pressure is 107/48 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of white blood cells (WBCs), but no leukocytosis or fever to support pneumonia. His lactate level is within normal range. His cardiac enzymes (CKs and troponins) are negative, and his electrocardiogram (EKG) shows no concerning ischemic changes.

The patient's medical conditions include COPD exacerbation, hypoxia, and hemoptysis. He is at risk for respiratory acidosis, which requires close monitoring and management.

The patient's anemia is likely related to dark nasal gastric (NG) lavage and small amount of suctioned blood, which may be secondary to ingested hempotysis or a nasopharyngeal/nosebleed.

The patient's hemoptysis may be due to Streptococcus pneumoniae (PNA) or complications from underlying asbestosis-related lung disease. A bronchoscopy showed possible source of bleeding in the posterior RUL bronchiectasis.

The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial, due to hypovolemia, acute volume loss, cardiac dysfunction with bradycardia, and possibly sepsis.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Continue respiratory support with invasive ventilation.
2. Trend ABGs as above.
3. Restart Advair, albuterol nebs, and Spiriva regimen.
4. Continue telemonitoring.
5. Repeat EKG and TTE.
6. Hold ASA for now given bleeding.
7. Trend Hct q6 hours.
8. Active T&S.
9. Supportive management.
10. Consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

1. Nutrition: start tube feeds.
2. Glycemic control.
3. Prophylaxis: DVT, pneumoboots, and stress ulcer with protonix drip.
4. VAP prevention.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is unknown.

   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p
   prior MI)who presents with new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration
   event in setting of hemoptysis vs. GI bleed.
   .
   #COPD Exacerbation / Hypoxia: Patient presumably desaturated secondary
   to acute COPD exacerbation from coughing, aspiration and bronchospasm
   in the setting of  hemoptysis vs. nasopharyngeal bleeding source
   w/aspiration( given elevated INR 3.8).  This acute aspiration paired
   with his poor baseline lung reserve with severe COPD & asbestosis
   related lung disease likely produced his hypoxia at OSH with
   desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was successfully
   intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC mode . He has no
   leukocytosis or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5 range -
   but this is also in the differential as RLL on CT chest  with
   concerning consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   .
   -continue current settings on AC mode
   -repeat ABG
   -wean to CPAP/PS as tolerates, then to NC
   -expand Abx coverage with CTX / Vanco/ Azithromycin
   -prednisone PO 60mg, will taper slowly

   .

   dark NG lavage and small amount suctioned (20cc). This GI collected
   blood may be secondary to ingested hempotysis source or from a
   nasopharyngeal /nosebleed in the setting of an elevated INR vs. true
   pulmonary source and overt hemoptysis.  Etiology of hemoptysis may be
   due Strep PNA vs. complications from underlying existing asbestosis
   related lung disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also
   possible new malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early
   [**2199-6-7**] at last cardiology appointment), however, there are no clear
   masses to support this on CT.
   .
   -continue trending Hct
   -q6 hours Hct checks
   -active T&S
   -guiac all stools
   -continue IV Protonix [**Hospital1 7**] for GI source coverage
   -consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding
   -f/up final CT chest read
   -INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA

   .

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

* The patient is a 91-year-old male with a history of hypertension, severe COPD, and CAD, who presents with respiratory distress, hemoptysis, and acute hypoxia.
* The patient was intubated and is currently on invasive ventilation, with a peak inspiratory pressure of 22 cmH2O and a plateau pressure of 18 cmH2O.
* The patient has a stable hemodynamic status, with a blood pressure of 107/48 mmHg and a heart rate of 65 bpm.
* The patient has a normal sinus rhythm, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on 40% FiO2.
* The patient has a mild anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.9 g/dL, and is receiving IV Protonix for GI source coverage.
* The patient has a history of COPD exacerbation, and his ABG results show a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 215, indicating a mild respiratory failure.
* The patient has a normal white blood cell count, with no signs of infection or inflammation.
* The patient has a history of MI, but his EKG and troponin levels are negative, and he is not receiving anticoagulation therapy.

Potential medical complications that may arise based on the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but he may experience further deterioration due to his underlying COPD and acute hypoxia.
2. Hemorrhage: The patient has a history of hemoptysis and may continue to bleed from the respiratory or GI tract.
3. Infection: The patient has a mild anemia and is receiving IV antibiotics, which may increase his risk of infection.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of CAD and hypertension, which may increase his risk of cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of COPD exacerbation and may experience neurological complications, such as respiratory failure or hypoxia-related encephalopathy.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple comorbidities and potential medical complications. Close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and GI status are essential to prevent further complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

   mycobacterial disease.  Limited blood through endotracheal tube.
   Monitor clinically.  Plan repeat bronchscopy for micro (including AFB).

 Perhaps pneumonia or bronchietasis.  Ceftriaxone, Vanco,

   trauma), exacerbated by anticoagulation (supratherapeutic).  Evidence
   for clinical stability by Hct.  Transfuse to Hct > 27.
   HYPONATREMIA -- unclear duration.  Resolved with NS.  Monitor Na.  [**Month (only) 51**]

   COAGULOPATHY --  attributed to coumadin.  Monitor PT.
   CAD -- no evidence for acute MI.  Monitor cardiac enzymes.

 hypovolemia.  Replete with NS.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure, hypotension, and suspected pneumonia or bronchiectasis. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a history of dormant TB and no known treatment. The patient's medical history is significant for COPD, asbestos-related lung disease, and hypertension.

The patient's current condition is marked by hypotension, requiring IV fluid boluses and vasopressors, as well as hypoxemia. The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia, which may be related to hemoptysis, ecchymosis, and anticoagulation therapy. The patient's coagulation profile shows evidence of coagulopathy, which is attributed to coumadin therapy.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Maintaining mechanical ventilation and monitoring ABG.
2. Treating infection with antibiotics.
3. Working towards spontaneous breathing trials (SBT).
4. Optimizing medical regimen for COPD.
5. Supporting blood pressure with vasopressors and fluids.
6. Assessing cardiac enzymes and cardiac function.
7. Monitoring for signs of sepsis.
8. Replenishing fluids to maintain MAP >60 mmHg.
9. Considering central line and vasopressors as needed.
10. Assessing for cardiac enzymes and cardiac function.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can worsen, leading to decreased perfusion and organ dysfunction.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can progress, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy can worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cardiac output.
6. Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia can worsen, leading to muscle cramps, tetany, and cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Hypomagnesemia: The patient's hypomagnesemia can worsen, leading to muscle cramps, weakness, and cardiac arrhythmias.

To prevent these complications, the patient's care should be closely monitored, and the plan of care should be adjusted accordingly. The patient's medical team should also consider consulting with specialists, such as pulmonologists and cardiologists, to optimize the patient's care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure, hypotension, and other significant medical conditions. Here is a summary of the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* Respiratory failure with unclear etiology, possibly related to COPD exacerbation, evolving pneumonia/bronchopneumonia, hemoptysis, and CHF on a background of asbestos-related lung disease.
* Hypotension, possibly due to hypovolemia, sepsis, or other causes.
* Anemia, likely multifactorial, with evidence of hemoptysis and ecchymosis.
* Hyponatremia, possibly related to lung disease or pneumonia.
* Coagulopathy, attributed to coumadin.
* CAD, no evidence of acute MI.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Pneumonia or bronchiectasis, possibly requiring further antibiotics and bronchoscopy.
* Sepsis, potentially life-threatening, requiring prompt recognition and treatment.
* Endobronchial blood clot, which may have obstructed the central airway, leading to respiratory distress.
* Aspiration pneumonia, due to the patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, MI, or cardiac failure, given the patient's history of CAD and HTN.
* Nutritional deficiencies, particularly protein-calorie malnutrition, due to the patient's inability to take food orally.
* Infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSIs), or pressure ulcers.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* Maintain mechanical ventilation and monitor ABG to optimize respiratory support.
* Treat infection with antibiotics, considering pneumonia, bronchiectasis, and mycobacterial disease.
* Support blood pressure with vasopressors and fluids, considering central line placement.
* Monitor cardiac enzymes and perform cardiac echo to assess cardiac function.
* Manage anemia with transfusions to maintain Hct > 27.
* Monitor sodium levels and consider initiating TF for nutritional support.
* Provide stress ulcer prophylaxis and DVT prophylaxis.
* Monitor for signs of sepsis, including fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status.
* Consider A-FIB and monitor HR, INR, and cardiac enzymes.

**Recommendations:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, respiratory status, and cardiac function closely.
* Consider repeating bronchoscopy for microbiological sampling and to assess the severity of the patient's respiratory failure.
* Initiate TF for nutritional support and monitor the patient's glucose levels to ensure glycemic control.
* Consider placing a central line for vasopressor administration and monitoring.
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust treatment accordingly.
* Continue to communicate with the patient's family and healthcare team to ensure that all parties are aware of the patient's condition and treatment plan.

 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p
   prior MI)who presents with new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration
   event in setting of hemoptysis vs. GI bleed.
   #COPD Exacerbation / resp acidosis/hemoptysis: Patient presumably
   desaturated secondary to acute COPD exacerbation from coughing,
   aspiration and bronchospasm in the setting of  and elevated INR of
   3.8.  This acute aspiration paired with his poor baseline lung reserve
   with severe COPD & asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his
   hypoxia at OSH with desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was
   successfully intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC
   mode.  Required bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday
   with evidence of RUL posterior segment bleed.  He has no leukocytosis
   or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5 range - but this is
   also in the differential as RLL on CT chest with concerning
   consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   - continue mechanical ventilation on CMV500/18/5/40%.  Monitor ABG and
   switch to PS when pt can clinically tolerate it.
   - ABG q am and 1 hour vent change
   - minimize sedation to help with hypotension, SBT today or tomorrow
   - continue CTX / Vanco/Azithromycin, 8-day course total
   - Decrease Prednisone to 40 mg PO qday starting [**8-9**] (from 60mg), for
   total [**11-20**] d course
   - albuterol/atrovent MDIs standing q6hrs.
   - f/u on ppd and [**Female First Name (un) **] antigen
   - f/u BAL and cx
   #Anemia: Stable overnight.  Hct drop between [**Date range (1) 8478**] from 42-> 38->
   36 -> 31 now s/p 1 unit PRBCs with hct 32.4 post xfusion to 31.5
   overnight.  Initial concern for GI bleed now decreased s/p clearance of
   clot from ETT during bronch on [**8-5**]. Etiology of hemoptysis may be due
   Strep PNA vs. complications from underlying existing asbestosis related
   lung disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also possible new
   malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early [**2199-6-7**] at
   last cardiology appointment), however, there are no clear masses to
   support this on CT.
   - continue trending Hct q8 hours, T&S active
   - low transfusion threshold, transfuse if Hct drops <30
   - if continue to bleed reverse anticoagulation with FFP, hold heparin
   for now
   -guiac all stools
   -continue IV Protonix [**Hospital1 7**] for GI source coverage
   -consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding
   -f/up final CT chest read
   -INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA
   - if Hct continues to decrease will contact IR for possible
   embolization, surgery for possible emergent thoracotomy, anesthesia to
   possibly place double lumen tube in non-bleeding bronchus
   - if cont active hemoptysis place patient on right side
   # hypotension: likely multifactorial due to hypovolemia, acute volume
   loss (low urine output), cardiac dysfunction with bradycardia.  Holding
   home antihypotensives.  High autopeep and sepsis less likely etiologies
   - wean sedation to help raise BP
   - supportive management with fluid boluses
   - RBC transfusion as needed
   - consider pressors if continues
   #Bradycardia: Pt bradycardic despite being hypotensive.  Possibilty of
   primary cardiac cause.  Echo and EKG completed.
   - wean sedation
   - Continue to monitor
   - consider transcutaneous pacing and/or atropine if unable to maintain
   pressure with bradycardia
   - treat hypotension as above
   #Decreased urine output
   #COPD-Longstanding history per family. Per daughter he is usually on
   2.5L NC at home, not 1.5L per OSH records.
   -trending ABGs as above
   -restart Advair, albuterol nebs, Spiriva regimen
   #History of MI: No recent note of any chest pain alongside his SOB
   complaints. CKs and troponins all negative at OSH and no concerning
   ischemic EKG changes.
   - holding ASA for now given bleeding
   - continue tele monitoring
   #HTN
 d/ced lisinopril 5mg, lasix 20mg
   #H/O arrhythmia: Initially unclear of why patient was on Warfarin and
   Sotolol but confirmed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] ( cardiologist) that both for pAF.
   NSR now on telemetry and EKG.

   --continue telemetry

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 94-year-old male with a significant medical history, including hypertension, severe COPD, and CAD (previous myocardial infarction). He was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, hemoptysis, and hypotension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: He is intubated and mechanically ventilated on a CMV mode with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* Cardiovascular: He is hypotensive, with a blood pressure of 103/35 mmHg, and bradycardic, with a heart rate of 49 beats per minute.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: His central venous pressure (CVP) is 8 mmHg, and his pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) is not available.
* Fluid balance: He has received a total of 5,395 mL of fluid, including 4,569 mL of intravenous fluids, 826 mL of blood products, and 427 mL of urine output.
* Laboratory results: His white blood cell count (WBC) is 9.3 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) is 10.2 g/dL, platelet count (Plt) is 199 K/uL, and his lactate level is 0.8 mmol/L.

The patient's diagnosis is likely acute COPD exacerbation with aspiration, hemoptysis, and hypotension. The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his severe COPD, which is complicated by aspiration and bronchospasm.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen if he does not receive adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can lead to organ dysfunction, including kidney failure and cardiovascular instability.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis can worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment, including bronchoscopic evaluation and possible embolization.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen if he continues to bleed and does not receive adequate transfusion support.
5. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia can worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment, including transcutaneous pacing and/or atropine.
6. Decreased urine output: The patient's decreased urine output can worsen if he does not receive adequate fluid resuscitation and vasopressor support.
7. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can worsen if he does not receive adequate antibiotic treatment and source control.
8. Malignancy: The patient's recent weight loss and lack of clear masses on CT scan suggest a possible underlying malignancy, which requires further evaluation.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Mechanical ventilation: The patient will continue to receive mechanical ventilation on a CMV mode.
2. Fluid resuscitation: The patient will receive fluid boluses as needed to maintain adequate blood pressure.
3. Blood transfusion: The patient will receive blood transfusions as needed to maintain an adequate hemoglobin level.
4. Antibiotic therapy: The patient will receive antibiotics to cover potential bacterial infections.
5. Bronchoscopic evaluation: The patient will undergo bronchoscopic evaluation to evaluate the cause of his hemoptysis.
6. Embolization: The patient may require embolization to control bleeding.
7. Cardiovascular support: The patient may require cardiovascular support, including pressors and vasopressors, to maintain adequate blood pressure.
8. Hemostatic therapy: The patient may require hemostatic therapy, including platelet transfusions and factor replacement, to control bleeding.

The patient's care plan should be closely monitored and adjusted as needed to ensure that he receives adequate treatment for his underlying conditions and potential complications.

**Summary:**

The patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease, and asbestosis-related lung disease. He presented with a new hypoxic episode, likely due to aspiration, and was intubated. He has been experiencing hemoptysis, hypotension, and bradycardia. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, bronchodilators, and corticosteroids.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pneumonia**: The patient's lung disease and recent aspiration event increase the risk of developing pneumonia.
2. **Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)**: The patient's severe COPD and asbestosis-related lung disease may predispose him to developing ARDS.
3. **Gastrointestinal (GI) Bleeding**: The patient's recent bleeding and decreased hemoglobin level increase the risk of further GI bleeding.
4. **Anemia**: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding and inadequate red blood cell transfusion.
5. **Hypotension**: The patient's hypotension may be due to hypovolemia, acute volume loss, cardiac dysfunction, or a combination of these factors. Further evaluation and management are necessary to optimize blood pressure.
6. **Bradycardia**: The patient's bradycardia may be due to primary cardiac cause, sedation, or hypotension. Further evaluation and management are necessary to optimize heart rate.
7. **Decreased Urine Output**: The patient's decreased urine output may be due to dehydration, hypotension, or underlying kidney disease. Further evaluation and management are necessary to optimize urine output.
8. **COPD Exacerbation**: The patient's COPD exacerbation may worsen due to ongoing bronchospasm, aspiration, and bronchial obstruction.
9. **Malignancy**: The patient's recent weight loss and lack of clear masses on CT scan raise concerns about potential underlying malignancy.
10. **Infection**: The patient's ongoing bleeding and decreased immune function increase the risk of developing infection.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and wean sedation to help raise blood pressure.
2. Monitor ABG and adjust ventilation accordingly.
3. Trend hemoglobin levels and transfuse as needed to maintain optimal hemoglobin levels.
4. Continue antibiotics and corticosteroids to manage potential infection and inflammation.
5. Consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding.
6. Continue to monitor and manage hypotension, bradycardia, and decreased urine output.
7. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis and continue to monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Continue to monitor for signs of infection and adjust management accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 91-year-old male with a significant medical history, including hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease (CAD) with a prior myocardial infarction (MI). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with a hypoxic episode, likely due to aspiration, and was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 100% on 40% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).
* Cardiovascular: He is bradycardic with a heart rate of 49 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 103/35 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: His central venous pressure (CVP) is 8 mmHg, and his cardiac index is not available.
* Laboratory results: His white blood cell count is 9.3 x 10^9/L, his hemoglobin is 10.2 g/dL, and his platelet count is 199 x 10^9/L. His lactate level is 1.5 mmol/L.
* Imaging studies: A computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest showed evidence of right upper lobe (RUL) posterior segment bleeding, but no clear masses to support a new malignancy.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Hemoptysis: The patient has been experiencing hemoptysis, which may be due to a pulmonary bleed, Strep pneumoniae, or complications from his underlying asbestosis-related lung disease.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which may be due to hypovolemia, acute volume loss, or cardiac dysfunction.
3. Respiratory acidosis: The patient has a respiratory acidosis, which may be due to his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and mechanical ventilation.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is decreasing, which may be due to bleeding or underlying chronic disease.
5. Possible sepsis: The patient's lactate level is elevated, which may indicate sepsis.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Mechanical ventilation: The patient will continue to be ventilated with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.
2. Sedation: The patient will be continued on sedation to facilitate mechanical ventilation.
3. Antibiotics: The patient will receive antibiotics to cover possible infections, including Strep pneumoniae.
4. Bronchoscopy: The patient will undergo bronchoscopy to evaluate the etiology of his hemoptysis.
5. Cardiovascular support: The patient will receive fluid boluses and may require vasopressors to support his blood pressure.
6. Anemia management: The patient's anemia will be managed with transfusions as necessary.
7. Gastrointestinal support: The patient will receive gastrointestinal support, including proton pump inhibitors and antacids, to manage his acid-base status.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient may develop pneumonia, particularly if he is colonized with Strep pneumoniae.
2. Sepsis: The patient may develop sepsis, particularly if he has a severe infection.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient may develop cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac failure, particularly if he has underlying cardiac disease.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient may develop respiratory failure, particularly if his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) worsens.
5. Bleeding: The patient may continue to bleed, particularly if his hemoptysis is due to a pulmonary bleed or complications from his underlying lung disease.

 HEMOPTYSIS
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p
   prior MI)who presents with new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration
   event in setting of hemoptysis vs. GI bleed.
   #COPD Exacerbation / resp acidosis/hemoptysis: Patient presumably
   desaturated secondary to acute COPD exacerbation from coughing,
   aspiration and bronchospasm in the setting of  and elevated INR of
   3.8.  This acute aspiration paired with his poor baseline lung reserve
   with severe COPD & asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his
   hypoxia at OSH with desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was
   successfully intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC
   mode.  Required bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday
   with evidence of RUL posterior segment bleed.  He has no leukocytosis
   or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5 range - but this is
   also in the differential as RLL on CT chest with concerning
   consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   .
   - continue mechanical ventilation on CMV500/18/5/40%.  Monitor ABG and
   switch to PS when pt can clinically tolerate it.
   - ABG q am and 1 hour vent change
   - minimize sedation to help with hypotension, SBT today or tomorrow
   - continue CTX / Vanco/Azithromycin, 8-day course total
   - Decrease Prednisone to 40 mg PO qday starting tomorrow (from 60mg),
   for total [**11-20**] d course
   - albuterol/atrovent MDIs standing q6hrs.
   - f/u on ppd and [**Female First Name (un) **] antigen
   - f/u BAL and cx
   #Anemia: Stable overnight.  Hct drop between [**Date range (1) 8478**] from 42-> 38->
   36 -> 31 now s/p 1 unit PRBCs with hct 32.4 post xfusion to 31.5
   overnight.  Initial concern for GI bleed now decreased s/p clearance of
   clot from ETT during bronch on [**8-5**]. Etiology of hemoptysis may be due
   Strep PNA vs. complications from underlying existing asbestosis related
   lung disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also possible new
   malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early [**2199-6-7**] at
   last cardiology appointment), however, there are no clear masses to
   support this on CT.
   - continue trending Hct q8 hours
   - active T&S
   - if Hct continues to decrease will contact IR for possible
   embolization, surgery for possible emergent thoracotomy, anesthesia to
   possibly place double lumen tube in non-bleeding bronchus
   - if cont active hemoptysis place patient on right side
   - if continue to bleed reverse anticoagulation with FFP, hold heparin
   for now
   -guiac all stools
   -continue IV Protonix [**Hospital1 7**] for GI source coverage
   -consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding
   -f/up final CT chest read
   -INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA
   -transfuse if Hct drops <30
   # hypotension: likely multifactorial due to hypovolemia, acute volume
   loss (low urine output), cardiac dysfunction with bradycardia.  Holding
   home antihypotensives.
   - high autopeep and sepsis less likely etiologies
   - repeat ECHO
   - supportive management with fluid boluses
   - RBC transfusion as needed
   - place arterial line, consider central line if pt does not improve
   with boluses and continuous pressure monitoring.
   .
   #COPD-Longstanding history per family. Per daughter he is usually on
   2.5L NC at home, not 1.5L per OSH records.
   -trending ABGs as above
   -restart Advair, albuterol nebs, Spiriva regimen
   .
   #History of MI: No recent note of any chest pain alongside his SOB
   complaints. CKs and troponins all negative at OSH and no concerning
   ischemic EKG changes.
   - holding ASA for now given bleeding
   - repeat EKG
   - TTE
   - continue tele monitoring
   .
   #HTN
 holding home meds [**3-11**] hypotension; d/ced lisinopril 5mg, lasix
   20mg
   .
   #H/O arrhythmia: Initially unclear of why patient was on Warfarin and
   Sotolol but confirmed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] ( cardiologist) that both for pAF.
   NSR now on telemetry and EKG.
   --holding Sotolol [**3-11**] hypotension
   --repeat EKG

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old male with a significant medical history, including hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease. He was admitted with new-onset hypoxia, likely due to acute COPD exacerbation with aspiration and bronchospasm. He was intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

The patient has been experiencing hemoptysis, which is being investigated. The etiology is unclear, but possible causes include Streptococcal pneumonia, asbestosis-related lung disease, or a new malignancy.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 103/35 mmHg, heart rate of 49 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He has a history of anemia, and his hemoglobin level has decreased from 42 to 31.5 g/dL over the past few days.

The patient has a number of medical complications, including hypotension, which is being managed with fluid boluses and supportive care. He also has a history of atrial fibrillation and is taking warfarin and sotalol, which are being held due to bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further respiratory failure.
2. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis is ongoing, and further bleeding could lead to complications such as respiratory failure or cardiac arrest.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is worsening, and further bleeding could exacerbate this condition.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial and may be due to hypovolemia, acute volume loss, and cardiac dysfunction. Further hypotension could lead to organ failure.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia, and further infection could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
7. Malignancy: The patient's hemoptysis could be due to a new malignancy, which could lead to further complications and poor outcomes.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
2. Investigate the etiology of the hemoptysis and manage accordingly.
3. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as necessary.
4. Manage the patient's hypotension with fluid boluses and supportive care.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and manage any arrhythmias or cardiac complications.
6. Consider further imaging studies, such as a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest, to evaluate the patient's lung disease and potential malignancy.
7. Consider consulting with a cardiologist or pulmonologist to further manage the patient's medical complications.

   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p
   prior MI)who presents with new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration
   event in setting of hemoptysis vs. GI bleed.
   #COPD Exacerbation / resp acidosis/hemoptysis: Patient presumably
   desaturated secondary to acute COPD exacerbation from coughing,
   aspiration and bronchospasm in the setting of  and elevated INR of
   3.8.  This acute aspiration paired with his poor baseline lung reserve
   with severe COPD & asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his
   hypoxia at OSH with desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was
   successfully intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC
   mode.  Required bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday
   with evidence of RUL posterior segment bleed.  He has no leukocytosis
   or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5 range - but this is
   also in the differential as RLL on CT chest  with concerning
   consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 91-year-old male with a significant medical history, including hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease (CAD) with a prior myocardial infarction (MI). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to a new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration event in the setting of hemoptysis vs. gastrointestinal (GI) bleed.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation on CMV mode with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* Cardiovascular status: He is bradycardic with a heart rate of 49 beats per minute and hypotensive with a blood pressure of 103/35 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: He has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 8 mmHg and a pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) not inserted.
* Fluid balance: He has received a total of 5,395 mL of fluid, with a positive balance of 4,968 mL.
* Laboratory results: His white blood cell count (WBC) is 9.3 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin (Hb) is 10.2 g/dL, and platelet count (Plt) is 199 x 10^9/L. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 23 mg/dL, creatinine (Cr) is 0.7 mg/dL, and lactate is 1.5 mmol/L.
* Imaging studies: His chest computed tomography (CT) scan shows severe pulmonary hypertension with hypertrophied, dilated, and mildly hypokinetic right ventricle, and preserved global and regional left ventricular systolic function.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further escalation of respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, and he has a fever, which may indicate the presence of sepsis.
3. Bleeding: The patient has ongoing hemoptysis, and his bleeding may be difficult to control.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's heart rate is bradycardic, and his blood pressure is hypotensive, which may indicate cardiovascular instability.
5. Renal failure: The patient's BUN and Cr levels are elevated, which may indicate renal failure.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of GI bleeding, and his bleeding may be ongoing.
7. Anemia: The patient's Hb level is low, and he may require further transfusions.
8. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for DVT due to his immobility and underlying medical conditions.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation on CMV mode.
2. Monitor ABG and switch to pressure support (PS) when the patient can clinically tolerate it.
3. Minimize sedation to help with hypotension.
4. Continue CTX, Vanco, and Azithromycin.
5. Decrease Prednisone to 40 mg PO qday.
6. Albuterol and atrovent MDIs standing q6hrs.
7. Follow up on ppd and [Female First Name (un)] antigen.
8. Follow up on BAL and cx.
9. Trend Hct q6 hours.
10. Active T&S.
11. Consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding.
12. Continue IV Protonix for GI source coverage.
13. Consider DVT prophylaxis with SCD.
14. Continue holding Coumadin and ASA.
15. Repeat ECHO.
16. Supportive management with fluid boluses.
17. RBC transfusion as needed.
18. Place arterial line and consider central line if the patient does not improve with boluses and continuous pressure monitoring.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure of unclear etiology. They have a history of COPD exacerbation, evolving pneumonia/bronchopneumonia, hemoptysis, and CHF on a background of asbestos-related lung disease. The patient experienced a hypotensive episode associated with low central venous pressure (CVP) and responded to IV fluid boluses. They continue to exhibit bradycardia.

The patient has a central line for more secure IV access, and a bronchoscopy was performed yesterday to assess for MTb disease. They have a history of allergies to penicillins, horse/Equine product derivatives, ragweed, and tetanus.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 35.4°C (95.7°F)
* Heart rate: 51 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/42 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Central venous pressure: 15 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* White blood cell count: 9.3
* Hematocrit: 32.9%
* Platelet count: 199 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood glucose: 136 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: Maintain mechanical ventilation, monitor ABG, treat infection, and work towards spontaneous breathing trial (SBT).
* COPD: Optimize medical regimen, including steroids.
* Hypotension: Continue to support blood pressure, consider vasopressors as needed.
* Coughing blood: Monitor clinically, consider repeat bronchoscopy for microbiological evaluation, and check PPD with controls.
* Pneumonia: Treat with antibiotics (Ceftriaxone, Vancomycin, and Azithromycin).
* Bradycardia: Monitor.
* Anemia: Transfuse to hematocrit > 27.
* Oliguria: Assess for proper catheter function.
* Hyponatremia: Monitor sodium levels and consider resolution with normal saline.
* Coagulopathy: Monitor PT and consider discontinuing Coumadin.
* CAD: Monitor cardiac enzymes.
* Fluids: Replete with normal saline due to hypovolemia.
* A-Fib: Monitor heart rate and anticoagulate as needed.
* Nutritional support: Initiate tube feeding.
* ICU care: Monitor for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to inadequate ventilation or infection
* Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to electrolyte imbalances or medication
* Sepsis or septic shock due to untreated infection
* Hemorrhage or bleeding due to coagulopathy or anticoagulation
* Renal failure due to hypovolemia or sepsis
* Electrolyte imbalances or acidosis due to inadequate fluid management or medication
* Skin breakdown or pressure ulcers due to immobility or poor circulation
* Worsening of underlying conditions, such as COPD or CHF.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely multifactorial, including COPD exacerbation, evolving pneumonia/bronchopneumonia, hemoptysis, and CHF on a background of asbestos-related lung disease. The patient requires continued mechanical ventilation and monitoring of ABG to manage their respiratory status.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to hypovolemia, sepsis, or other factors. The patient requires continued support to maintain a MAP >60 mmHg, and vasopressors may be necessary if the hypotension persists.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis is likely related to bronchiectasis or mycobacterial disease. Repeat bronchoscopy is planned to rule out these conditions, and the patient requires monitoring for any signs of bleeding or respiratory distress.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is multifactorial, including hemoptysis, ecchymosis, and anticoagulation. The patient requires transfusion to maintain a Hct >27.
5. Oliguria: The patient's oliguria may be due to hypovolemia or other factors. The patient requires assessment for proper catheter function and monitoring of fluid status.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may be due to lung disease or pneumonia. The patient requires monitoring of sodium levels and treatment with NS as needed.
7. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is attributed to coumadin. The patient requires monitoring of PT and INR levels.
8. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia is likely related to intrinsic lung disease or vagal stimulation. The patient requires monitoring of heart rate and rhythm.
9. Nutritional support: The patient requires initiation of TF and monitoring of nutritional status.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiovascular, and hematological status.

   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p

   #COPD Exacerbation / resp acidosis/hemoptysis: Patient presumably

   aspiration and bronchospasm in the setting of  and elevated INR of
   3.8.  This acute aspiration paired with his poor baseline lung reserve
   with severe COPD & asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his
   hypoxia at OSH with desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was
   successfully intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC
   mode.  Required bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday
   with evidence of RUL posterior segment bleed.  He has no leukocytosis
   or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5 range - but this is
   also in the differential as RLL on CT chest with concerning
   consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   - continue mechanical ventilation on CMV500/18/5/40%.  Monitor ABG and
   switch to PS when pt can clinically tolerate it.

   #Anemia: Stable overnight.  Hct drop between [**Date range (1) 8478**] from 42-> 38->
   36 -> 31 now s/p 1 unit PRBCs with hct 32.4 post xfusion to 31.5
   overnight.  Initial concern for GI bleed now decreased s/p clearance of
   clot from ETT during bronch on [**8-5**]. Etiology of hemoptysis may be due

   lung disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also possible new
   malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early [**2199-6-7**] at

   - continue trending Hct q8 hours, T&S active

   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p
   prior MI)who presents with new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration
   event in setting of hemoptysis vs. GI bleed.
   #COPD Exacerbation / resp acidosis/hemoptysis: Patient presumably
   desaturated secondary to acute COPD exacerbation from coughing,
   aspiration and bronchospasm in the setting of  and elevated INR of
   3.8.  This acute aspiration paired with his poor baseline lung reserve
   with severe COPD & asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his
   hypoxia at OSH with desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was
   successfully intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC
   mode.  Required bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday
   with evidence of RUL posterior segment bleed.  He has no leukocytosis
   or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5 range - but this is
   also in the differential as RLL on CT chest with concerning
   consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   - continue mechanical ventilation on CMV500/18/5/40%.  Monitor ABG and
   switch to PS when pt can clinically tolerate it.
   - ABG q am and 1 hour vent change
   - minimize sedation to help with hypotension, SBT today or tomorrow
   - continue CTX / Vanco/Azithromycin, 8-day course total
   - Decrease Prednisone to 40 mg PO qday starting [**8-9**] (from 60mg), for
   total [**11-20**] d course
   - albuterol/atrovent MDIs standing q6hrs.
   - f/u on ppd and [**Female First Name (un) **] antigen
   - f/u BAL and cx
   #Anemia: Stable overnight.  Hct drop between [**Date range (1) 8478**] from 42-> 38->
   36 -> 31 now s/p 1 unit PRBCs with hct 32.4 post xfusion to 31.5
   overnight.  Initial concern for GI bleed now decreased s/p clearance of
   clot from ETT during bronch on [**8-5**]. Etiology of hemoptysis may be due
   Strep PNA vs. complications from underlying existing asbestosis related
   lung disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also possible new
   malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early [**2199-6-7**] at
   last cardiology appointment), however, there are no clear masses to
   support this on CT.
   - continue trending Hct q8 hours, T&S active
   - low transfusion threshold, transfuse if Hct drops <30
   - if continue to bleed reverse anticoagulation with FFP, hold heparin
   for now
   -guiac all stools

   -f/up final CT chest read
   -INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA
   - if Hct continues to decrease will contact IR for possible
   embolization, surgery for possible emergent thoracotomy, anesthesia to
   possibly place double lumen tube in non-bleeding bronchus
   - if cont active hemoptysis place patient on right side
   # hypotension: likely multifactorial due to hypovolemia, acute volume
   loss (low urine output), cardiac dysfunction with bradycardia.  Holding
   home antihypotensives.  High autopeep and sepsis less likely etiologies
   - wean sedation to help raise BP
   - supportive management with fluid boluses
   - RBC transfusion as needed

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old male with a significant past medical history of hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with a new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration event in the setting of hemoptysis vs. gastrointestinal (GI) bleed.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: Mechanically ventilated on CMV mode with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* Cardiovascular status: Bradycardia with a heart rate of 55 beats per minute, blood pressure of 113/43 mmHg, and central venous pressure (CVP) of 10 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's cardiac output is likely to be decreased due to bradycardia and hypotension.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received 2,120 mL of fluid over the past 24 hours, with a total output of 625 mL.
* Laboratory results:
	+ White blood cell count (WBC): 7.4 K/uL
	+ Hemoglobin (Hb): 10.3 g/dL
	+ Platelet count (Plt): 199 K/uL
	+ Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 26 mg/dL
	+ Creatinine (Cr): 0.8 mg/dL
	+ Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Assessment and plan:
	+ The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial, including hypovolemia, acute volume loss, and cardiac dysfunction.
	+ The patient's anemia is stable, but the hemoglobin level has decreased from 42% to 31.5% overnight.
	+ The patient's hemoptysis is likely due to Streptococcus pneumoniae (Strep PNA) vs. complications from underlying asbestosis-related lung disease or a new malignancy.
	+ The patient's bradycardia is likely primary, but the etiology is unclear.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and further deterioration may occur if the mechanical ventilation settings are not optimized.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's bradycardia and hypotension may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or cardiogenic shock.
3. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's hemoptysis may worsen, leading to significant bleeding and potential respiratory compromise.
4. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and respiratory failure increase the risk of pneumonia or other infections.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's respiratory failure and mechanical ventilation may lead to malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances if not managed appropriately.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's hemoptysis may be due to GI bleeding, which may worsen and lead to significant bleeding and potential respiratory compromise.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's bradycardia may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or other arrhythmias.

To prevent or manage these potential complications, the patient should receive:

1. Optimal mechanical ventilation settings to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Close monitoring of cardiovascular status, including blood pressure, heart rate, and CVP.
3. Aggressive fluid management to prevent hypovolemia and maintain adequate blood pressure.
4. Sedation management to minimize respiratory and cardiovascular instability.
5. Antibiotic therapy to treat potential infections.
6. Nutritional support to prevent malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances.
7. Close monitoring of hemoptysis and GI bleeding, with prompt intervention if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old male with a significant medical history, including hypertension, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease (CAD) with a prior myocardial infarction (MI). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with a new hypoxic episode and hemoptysis, which was likely related to an acute COPD exacerbation and aspiration event.

The patient has been intubated and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation on assist-control mode. He is sedated with midazolam and fentanyl, and his blood pressure is being closely monitored due to concerns about hypotension and blood pressure lability.

The patient's laboratory results show a normal complete blood count (CBC) with a slight anemia, and his electrolyte levels are within normal limits. His liver function tests (LFTs) are normal, and his renal function is stable with a normal creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level.

The patient's radiology reports show a right upper lobe posterior segment bleed, which is being monitored closely. His chest X-ray (CXR) shows a right lung infiltrate, which is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is being closely monitored due to concerns about hypotension and blood pressure lability.
2. Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is slow, and he is being closely monitored for signs of cardiac instability.
3. Decreased urine output: The patient's urine output is decreased, but his creatinine and BUN levels are normal.
4. Anemia: The patient has a slight anemia, which is being monitored closely.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to his severe COPD and acute respiratory failure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Mechanical ventilation: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation on assist-control mode to support his respiratory function.
2. Sedation: The patient is being sedated with midazolam and fentanyl to minimize his discomfort and anxiety.
3. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics to treat his suspected bacterial pneumonia.
4. Bronchodilators: The patient is receiving bronchodilators to help improve his lung function.
5. Fluid management: The patient's fluid status is being closely monitored to ensure that he is not over- or under-resuscitated.
6. Blood transfusion: The patient may require blood transfusion if his hemoglobin level drops below 30.
7. Cardiac monitoring: The patient's cardiac status is being closely monitored due to his history of CAD and MI.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of CAD and MI makes him at risk for cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's severe COPD and acute respiratory failure make him at risk for respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's suspected bacterial pneumonia makes him at risk for sepsis.
4. Bleeding: The patient's history of bleeding and his current bleeding diathesis make him at risk for further bleeding.
5. Organ failure: The patient's multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) makes him at risk for organ failure.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including hypotension, bradycardia, decreased urine output, anemia, and respiratory failure. His treatment plan includes mechanical ventilation, sedation, antibiotics, bronchodilators, fluid management, and blood transfusion. His potential medical complications include cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, sepsis, bleeding, and organ failure.

 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old male with PMH significant for HTN, severe COPD, CAD ( s/p
   prior MI)who presents with new hypoxic episode with likely aspiration
   event in setting of hemoptysis vs. GI bleed.
   #COPD Exacerbation / resp acidosis/hemoptysis: Patient presumably
   desaturated secondary to acute COPD exacerbation from coughing,
   aspiration and bronchospasm in the setting of  and elevated INR of
   3.8.  This acute aspiration paired with his poor baseline lung reserve
   with severe COPD & asbestosis related lung disease likely produced his
   hypoxia at OSH with desaturations to 70s even on high flow NRB. He was
   successfully intubated and is now comfortable with sedation on AC
   mode.  Required bronch for obstruction/eval of hemoptosis yesterday
   with evidence of RUL posterior segment bleed.  He has no leukocytosis
   or report of fevers to support PNA and lactate 1.5 range - but this is
   also in the differential as RLL on CT chest with concerning
   consolidation vs. aspiration related changes.
   - continue mechanical ventilation on CMV500/18/5/40%.  Monitor ABG and
   switch to PS when pt can clinically tolerate it.
   - ABG q am and 1 hour vent change
   - minimize sedation to help with hypotension, SBT today or tomorrow
   - continue CTX / Vanco/Azithromycin, 8-day course total
   - Decrease Prednisone to 40 mg PO qday starting [**8-9**] (from 60mg), for
   total [**11-20**] d course
   - albuterol/atrovent MDIs standing q6hrs.
   - f/u on ppd and [**Female First Name (un) **] antigen
   - f/u BAL and cx
   #Anemia: Stable overnight.  Hct drop between [**Date range (1) 8478**] from 42-> 38->
   36 -> 31 now s/p 1 unit PRBCs with hct 32.4 post xfusion to 31.5
   overnight.  Initial concern for GI bleed now decreased s/p clearance of
   clot from ETT during bronch on [**8-5**]. Etiology of hemoptysis may be due
   Strep PNA vs. complications from underlying existing asbestosis related
   lung disease, although this would be quite atypical. Also possible new
   malignancy (recently losing weight; 183--> 177 in early [**2199-6-7**] at
   last cardiology appointment), however, there are no clear masses to
   support this on CT.
   - continue trending Hct q8 hours, T&S active
   - low transfusion threshold, transfuse if Hct drops <30
   - if continue to bleed reverse anticoagulation with FFP, hold heparin
   for now
   -guiac all stools
   -continue IV Protonix [**Hospital1 7**] for GI source coverage
   -consider GI scope if repeat NG suction with more bleeding
   -f/up final CT chest read
   -INR therapeutic at 2.1, continue holding Coumadin/ASA
   - if Hct continues to decrease will contact IR for possible
   embolization, surgery for possible emergent thoracotomy, anesthesia to
   possibly place double lumen tube in non-bleeding bronchus
   - if cont active hemoptysis place patient on right side
   # hypotension: likely multifactorial due to hypovolemia, acute volume
   loss (low urine output), cardiac dysfunction with bradycardia.  Holding

   - wean sedation to help raise BP

   - treat hypotension as above

   - UA, urine lytes, urine eosiniphils
   - monitor UOP
   #COPD-Longstanding history per family. Per daughter he is usually on
   2.5L NC at home, not 1.5L per OSH records.
   -trending ABGs as above
   -restart Advair, albuterol nebs, Spiriva regimen
   #History of MI: No recent note of any chest pain alongside his SOB
   complaints. CKs and troponins all negative at OSH and no concerning
   ischemic EKG changes.
   - holding ASA for now given bleeding
   - continue tele monitoring

 d/ced lisinopril 5mg, lasix 20mg
